title: First Aid and Emergency Response
subject: Health and Physical Education
substrand: Safety, Risk Management and Protective Behaviours
description: This topic explores first aid principles, emergency response procedures, CPR awareness, and responding to common injuries and medical emergencies. Students develop knowledge and skills to respond effectively in emergency situations.
curriculumDescriptions: Plan, rehearse and evaluate strategies for managing situations where their own or others' safety may be at risk
Investigate and select strategies to promote health, safety and wellbeing

A.title: First Aid and Emergency Response - Foundation
A.levelDescription: Students working 2-3 years below the expected level will focus on recognising emergencies, calling for help, basic safety around injured people, and simple first aid concepts.
A.contentAdaptations: Uses simple language, visual supports, step-by-step instructions, and focuses on calling for help and staying safe. Emphasises knowing when to get adult help.

contentSections.title: Recognising Emergencies
contentSections.content: An emergency is when someone needs help right away. You might recognise an emergency if someone: is badly hurt and in pain, can't breathe properly, won't wake up, is having a fit, is bleeding a lot, or has been in an accident. If you're not sure if it's an emergency, it's always safer to get help. Telling an adult or calling for help is the right thing to do.

contentSections.title: Calling Triple Zero (000)
contentSections.content: In Australia, Triple Zero (000) is the number to call for emergencies. When you call, you will be asked: What service do you need? (Police, Fire, or Ambulance). Then they will ask: What is the address? What happened? The person on the phone will help you and send help. Stay on the line and answer their questions. Stay calm and speak clearly.

contentSections.title: Staying Safe at an Emergency
contentSections.content: When someone is hurt, you need to stay safe too. First, check if there is any danger to you - like cars, fire, or electricity. Don't run into danger to help someone. If it's safe, stay with the person and talk to them calmly. Don't move someone who is badly hurt unless there is danger. Get an adult to help as soon as you can.

contentSections.title: Simple Ways to Help
contentSections.content: While waiting for help, there are simple things you can do. Stay with the person and talk to them calmly. Put a blanket over them to keep them warm. If they have a small cut, you can help clean it with water. If an adult is doing first aid, you can help by getting things they need or keeping other people away. Sometimes the best help is just being there and keeping the person calm.

remember.question: What number do you call in Australia for an emergency?

options.feedback: 111 is an emergency number in some countries but not Australia.

options.text: 000 (Triple Zero)
options.feedback: Correct! Triple Zero (000) is Australia's emergency number for police, fire, and ambulance.
911 is the emergency number in the USA, not Australia.
123 is not an emergency number in Australia.

understand.question: Why is it important to check for danger before helping someone who is hurt?

options.text: Because you might get scared
options.feedback: Checking for danger is about safety, not fear.

options.text: Because you need to stay safe yourself so you can help
options.feedback: Correct! If you get hurt too, you can't help and there's now an extra person who needs rescuing.

options.text: Because it wastes time
options.feedback: Actually, checking for danger helps ensure you can provide safe and effective help.

options.text: Because the hurt person might be dangerous
options.feedback: We check for danger from the environment (like cars or fire), not usually from the injured person.

apply.question: You're at the park and you see someone fall and they're not moving. What should you do first?

options.text: Run over and shake them to wake them up
options.feedback: Moving someone who is hurt could make injuries worse. Check for danger first and get adult help.

options.text: Go home because you don't know them
options.feedback: When someone needs help, we should try to help by getting an adult or calling for help.

options.text: Check if it's safe, then call for an adult or call Triple Zero
options.feedback: Correct! Check for danger, then get help by finding an adult or calling Triple Zero.

options.text: Take a photo to show your friends
options.feedback: When someone is hurt, the priority is getting them help, not taking photos.

analyse.question: Look at these two situations. Which one is an emergency where you should call Triple Zero? Explain why. Situation A: Your friend fell over and has a small graze on their knee. Situation B: Your grandparent collapses and won't wake up when you call their name.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should identify Situation B as the emergency. They should explain that Situation A is minor (small injury that can be handled with basic first aid) while Situation B is serious (person is unconscious). Key indicators include: won't wake up, collapsed suddenly, and could be life-threatening.
successCriteria: Correctly identifies Situation B as the emergency
Explains that Situation A is minor and doesn't need Triple Zero
Gives reasons why Situation B is serious
Shows understanding of what makes something an emergency

evaluate.question: A friend says 'I would never call Triple Zero because I might get in trouble for wasting their time.' Is this good thinking? Explain why or why not.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should explain that this is not good thinking. Calling Triple Zero when you think someone needs help is always okay, even if you're not sure. The operators are trained to help and will guide you. It's better to call and not need help than to not call when someone does need help.
successCriteria: Explains that calling when unsure is okay
Notes that operators will help guide you
Identifies that not calling could be dangerous
Shows understanding that getting help is more important than worry about 'wasting time'

create.question: Create a poster that shows the steps to follow when you find someone who is hurt. Use pictures or words.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a simple poster showing emergency steps. Should include: check for danger, call for help (Triple Zero or adult), stay with the person, keep them calm. Poster should be clear and easy to follow.
successCriteria: Includes checking for danger as a first step
Shows how to call for help
Includes staying with the person
Is clear and easy to understand

unistructural.stem: What is the first thing you should do when you see someone is hurt?
unistructural.modelResponse: The first thing to do is check if it's safe (check for danger).
unistructural.rubric: Identifies checking for danger or ensuring safety as the first step.

multistructural.stem: List three things the Triple Zero operator will ask you.
multistructural.modelResponse: Three things the Triple Zero operator will ask are: 1) What service do you need? (Police, Fire, or Ambulance), 2) What is the address?, 3) What happened?
multistructural.rubric: Lists three relevant questions that may include: which service, address/location, what happened, person's condition, or caller's name.

relational.stem: Explain why you should stay on the line when you call Triple Zero until they say you can hang up.
relational.modelResponse: You should stay on the line because the operator might have more questions to help send the right help. They can also give you instructions on what to do while you wait. If the situation changes, you can tell them. They might also need to check the address or get more details about what happened. Hanging up early could mean important information is missed.
relational.rubric: Explains that staying on the line helps provide complete information. Shows understanding that operators may give instructions or ask follow-up questions.

extendedAbstract.stem: Think about why learning about first aid is important for everyone, not just doctors and nurses.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: First aid is important for everyone because emergencies can happen anywhere and anytime - at home, school, or in public. Doctors and nurses usually aren't right there when accidents happen. The first minutes are often the most important, and the people nearby are the first ones who can help. Even young people can help by calling Triple Zero, staying with the person, and keeping them calm. When more people know first aid, communities are safer because there's a better chance someone nearby will know what to do. It gives people confidence to help instead of just watching.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Connects first aid knowledge to community safety. Recognises that anyone can be first on scene. Shows understanding of why widespread knowledge matters.

reflectionQuestions: Do you know your home address to tell the Triple Zero operator?
Have you ever seen someone get help from emergency services?
Who would you get if there was an emergency at school?
selfAssessment: I can recognise when someone needs emergency help
I know how to call Triple Zero

studentReflection.connectionToLife: Knowing how to recognise emergencies and call for help is a skill you can use for your whole life. Even young people can save lives by getting help quickly.

The path that air takes from your nose and mouth to your lungs

contentSections.title: The DRSABCD Action Plan
contentSections.content: DRSABCD is an easy way to remember what to do in an emergency. D is for Danger - check that it's safe for you and the person. R is for Response - ask 'Can you hear me?' and gently squeeze their shoulders. S is for Send for help - call Triple Zero or ask someone else to. A is for Airway - make sure nothing is blocking their throat. B is for Breathing - look, listen and feel for breathing. C is for CPR - if they're not breathing, start CPR (if you're trained). D is for Defibrillator - use an AED if available (if you're trained).

contentSections.title: Responding to Bleeding
contentSections.content: If someone is bleeding from a cut or wound, you can help stop the bleeding. First, put on gloves if you have them. Press firmly on the wound with a clean cloth or bandage. Keep pressing and don't keep checking - this helps the blood clot. If possible, raise the injured part higher than the heart. If blood soaks through, add more pads on top - don't remove the first one. For very serious bleeding, call Triple Zero.

contentSections.title: Burns and Scalds
contentSections.content: Burns happen from heat, chemicals, or electricity. For minor burns: cool the burn under cool running water for 20 minutes. Don't use ice, butter, or creams. Cover with a clean, loose bandage. Don't pop any blisters. For serious burns (large area, on face/hands/joints, or very deep), call Triple Zero after cooling. Cool first, then cover and get help.

contentSections.title: The Recovery Position
contentSections.content: If someone is unconscious (won't wake up) but is breathing, put them in the recovery position. This keeps their airway clear and stops them choking. To do this: kneel beside them, place their arm nearest you out at right angle, bring their other arm across their chest, bend their far leg up, roll them towards you onto their side, tilt their head back to open the airway. Stay with them and keep checking their breathing until help arrives.

options.text: Danger, Response, Send for help, Airway, Breathing, CPR, Defibrillator
options.feedback: Correct! These are the steps to follow when helping someone in an emergency.

options.text: Doctor, Rescue, Safety, Ambulance, Bandage, Call, Drive
options.feedback: This isn't correct. DRSABCD stands for Danger, Response, Send for help, Airway, Breathing, CPR, Defibrillator.

options.text: Don't Run, Stay, Ask, Be calm, Check, Do
options.feedback: This isn't correct. DRSABCD is a specific emergency action plan.

options.text: Dial, Respond, Speak, Act, Breathe, Care, Done
options.feedback: This isn't correct. DRSABCD stands for Danger, Response, Send for help, Airway, Breathing, CPR, Defibrillator.

understand.question: Why should you cool a burn for 20 minutes under running water?

options.text: To clean off any dirt
options.feedback: While it does help clean, the main purpose is to cool the burn and reduce damage.

options.text: To cool the burn, reduce tissue damage, and ease pain
options.feedback: Correct! Cooling for 20 minutes stops the burning process, reduces damage to tissue, and helps with pain.

options.text: To make the person feel better emotionally
options.feedback: While they might feel more cared for, the main reason is medical - to treat the burn.

options.text: Because that's how long an ambulance takes
options.feedback: The 20 minutes is about proper burn treatment, not ambulance timing.

apply.question: Your friend cuts their hand while cooking and it's bleeding. What should you do?

options.text: Put butter on it to stop the bleeding
options.feedback: Never put butter on wounds - use pressure with a clean cloth.

options.text: Put on gloves if available, press firmly with a clean cloth, and raise the hand up
options.feedback: Correct! Applying pressure with a clean cloth and raising the wound helps stop bleeding.

options.text: Tell them to hold it under hot water
options.feedback: Hot water is for burns treatment, not bleeding. Use pressure to stop bleeding.

options.text: Leave them alone - blood is scary
options.feedback: Bleeding needs attention. Even if you're nervous, you can help by getting an adult or applying pressure.

analyse.question: Explain why the recovery position is important for someone who is unconscious but breathing.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should explain that the recovery position: keeps the airway open so they can breathe, prevents them from choking on vomit or saliva, uses gravity to help fluids drain out of the mouth rather than into the lungs, and keeps them stable in a safe position. Shows understanding of why positioning matters for unconscious people.
successCriteria: Explains that it keeps the airway open
Mentions preventing choking on fluids
Shows understanding of why unconscious people need this
Demonstrates understanding of the safety purpose

evaluate.question: Someone says 'If you're not trained in CPR, you shouldn't do anything for someone who isn't breathing.' Evaluate this statement.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate this critically. While formal CPR training is valuable, untrained people can still help: they can call Triple Zero immediately, the operator will give CPR instructions over the phone, attempting hands-only CPR is better than doing nothing if someone isn't breathing. Not doing anything when someone's heart has stopped means they will die. Some action is better than none.
successCriteria: Recognises that formal training helps but isn't the only factor
Notes that Triple Zero can give instructions
Understands that some action is better than none
Shows balanced evaluation of training vs. inaction

create.question: Create a step-by-step guide for responding to someone who has burned their arm on the stove.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a practical guide including: ensure safety (turn off stove if on), cool the burn under cool running water for 20 minutes, don't use ice or creams, cover with a loose clean bandage, don't pop blisters, get medical help if the burn is serious (large, deep, or on sensitive areas). Guide should be clear and in logical order.
successCriteria: Includes ensuring safety first
Specifies cooling under running water for 20 minutes
Mentions not using ice or creams
Includes when to get medical help

unistructural.stem: What is the first letter in DRSABCD and what does it stand for?
unistructural.modelResponse: The first letter is D, which stands for Danger - checking if it's safe.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly identifies D for Danger and explains it means checking for safety.

multistructural.stem: List the four steps for treating a minor burn.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four steps for treating a minor burn are: 1) Cool under running water for 20 minutes, 2) Don't use ice, butter or creams, 3) Cover with a clean loose bandage, 4) Don't pop any blisters.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant burn treatment steps including cooling, avoiding inappropriate treatments, covering, and not popping blisters.

relational.stem: Explain how the steps of DRSABCD work together to help someone in an emergency.
relational.modelResponse: The steps of DRSABCD work together in a logical order. You start with Danger to make sure you won't get hurt too - if you're hurt, you can't help. Response tells you if the person is conscious and can help themselves, or if they need more help. Send for help ensures professional help is on the way while you do what you can. Airway and Breathing check the most critical life functions - people can only survive minutes without breathing. If they're not breathing, CPR keeps blood and oxygen moving until the Defibrillator can restart the heart. Each step builds on the last, and following the order makes sure the most important things are done first.
relational.rubric: Explains how steps follow a logical order. Shows understanding of why early steps come first. Demonstrates how the sequence prioritises life-threatening issues.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider why every school should have students who know basic first aid. How does this make the school community safer?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Schools with students who know first aid are safer communities. Students are often the first to notice when peers are hurt or sick - they're right there in classrooms, playgrounds, and sports. More first aiders means faster response no matter where an incident happens. Students can start basic care while getting adult help, reducing the time to treatment. It also builds a culture of care and responsibility - students look out for each other. Learning first aid gives students confidence to act instead of freezing. It also benefits families and communities when students take these skills home. In a true emergency, every minute matters, and having many people with basic knowledge means help is always nearby.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies multiple benefits of widespread first aid knowledge. Connects student presence throughout school to response capability. Shows understanding of how first aid knowledge creates safer communities.

reflectionQuestions: Can you remember the DRSABCD steps without looking?
Have you ever seen first aid being given? What happened?
Do you know where the first aid kit is at home and at school?

studentReflection.connectionToLife: Knowing DRSABCD and basic first aid gives you the knowledge to help in many emergency situations. These skills can make a real difference for family, friends, and people in your community.

vocabularyTerms.definition: Emergency procedure combining chest compressions and rescue breaths to maintain blood flow when the heart stops
A portable device that can analyse heart rhythm and deliver an electric shock to restart the heart
A break or crack in a bone
An injury to ligaments around a joint caused by stretching or tearing

contentSections.title: Applying DRSABCD
contentSections.content: DRSABCD should be applied systematically in every emergency. After checking for Danger and Response, Send for help - either call Triple Zero yourself or direct a specific person to do so. For Airway, tilt the head back and lift the chin to open the airway; check for obstructions. For Breathing, look for chest rise, listen for breath sounds, and feel for breath on your cheek for up to 10 seconds. If not breathing normally, begin CPR (if trained) with 30 compressions to 2 breaths, pushing hard and fast in the centre of the chest. Use an AED as soon as one is available - the machine will guide you with voice prompts.

contentSections.title: Managing Injuries
contentSections.content: Different injuries require different responses. For fractures: keep the injured part still, support it with padding, don't try to straighten it, and seek medical help. For sprains: use RICER - Rest, Ice (wrapped, 20 minutes), Compression, Elevation, Referral to medical help. For severe bleeding: apply firm pressure with a clean pad, don't remove blood-soaked dressings (add more on top), elevate if possible, and call Triple Zero for life-threatening bleeding. For shock: lie the person down, raise their legs, keep them warm, and call Triple Zero.

contentSections.title: Medical Emergencies
contentSections.content: Some emergencies are medical conditions rather than injuries. For asthma: help the person sit upright, help them use their blue reliever inhaler (4 puffs, wait 4 minutes, repeat if needed), call Triple Zero if no improvement. For anaphylaxis: call Triple Zero immediately, help the person use their adrenaline autoinjector if they have one, position them comfortably (sitting if breathing difficulty, lying if low blood pressure). For seizures: move dangers away, don't restrain them, protect their head with padding, time the seizure, call Triple Zero if it lasts more than 5 minutes or is their first seizure.

contentSections.title: Emergency Planning
contentSections.content: Planning for emergencies improves response. This includes: knowing where first aid kits and AEDs are located, knowing emergency exits and meeting points, having emergency contact numbers accessible, identifying people with medical conditions and knowing their action plans, and practising emergency procedures regularly. After any emergency response, evaluation helps improve future responses. Consider: What went well? What could be improved? Was help called quickly enough? Were first aid procedures followed correctly?

remember.question: What is the compression-to-breath ratio in CPR for an adult?

options.text: 15 compressions to 2 breaths
options.feedback: This ratio is used for children in two-person CPR. For adults, it's 30:2.

options.text: 30 compressions to 2 breaths
options.feedback: Correct! In adult CPR, you give 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths.

options.text: 10 compressions to 1 breath
options.feedback: This isn't the recommended ratio. For adults, it's 30 compressions to 2 breaths.

options.text: 5 compressions to 1 breath
options.feedback: This isn't the recommended ratio. For adults, it's 30 compressions to 2 breaths.

understand.question: Why is it important not to remove a blood-soaked dressing but to add more on top?

options.text: Because it's too difficult to remove
options.feedback: The reason is medical, not about difficulty.

options.text: Because removing the dressing would disturb clotting and cause more bleeding
options.feedback: Correct! The blood-soaked dressing is part of the clotting process. Removing it breaks the forming clot and restarts bleeding.

options.text: Because you might see the wound and feel sick
options.feedback: The reason is about effective treatment, not about what you might see.

options.text: Because you need evidence for the ambulance
options.feedback: The reason is about stopping the bleeding effectively, not documentation.

apply.question: You're at school and a classmate says they feel dizzy, their skin is pale and sweaty, and they collapse. Apply your knowledge to identify what might be happening and what to do.

options.text: They're just tired - tell them to sleep it off
options.feedback: These symptoms could indicate shock or another serious condition. This needs proper first aid response.

options.text: This might be shock - follow DRSABCD, if breathing put in recovery position, raise their legs, keep warm, call for help
options.feedback: Correct! These are symptoms of shock. Following DRSABCD, supporting circulation, and calling for help is the right response.

options.text: Make them drink lots of water immediately
options.feedback: Giving fluids to someone who is unconscious or may vomit is dangerous. Follow DRSABCD and get help.

options.text: Shake them vigorously to wake them up
options.feedback: Shaking could cause injury. Use gentle response check (talk, shoulder squeeze) as part of DRSABCD.

analyse.question: Analyse why AEDs (defibrillators) have been placed in many public locations like shopping centres and sports facilities.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. Key points: cardiac arrest can happen anywhere, survival rates drop rapidly with each minute, AEDs can be used by bystanders with voice prompts (don't need extensive training), early defibrillation dramatically improves survival, public locations have many people at any time. Strong responses connect timing of defibrillation to survival statistics.
successCriteria: Explains that cardiac arrest can happen anywhere
Discusses how survival depends on quick treatment
Notes that AEDs are designed for public use
Analyses how availability improves emergency outcomes

evaluate.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of your school's emergency response procedures. What works well and what could be improved?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students evaluate their school's procedures considering: clarity of roles, access to first aid equipment and trained staff, communication systems, regularity of drills, student knowledge of procedures, locations of AEDs and first aid kits. Evaluation should identify both strengths and areas for improvement with reasoning.
successCriteria: Identifies specific strengths of current procedures
Identifies specific areas for improvement
Provides reasoning for evaluative judgments
Considers multiple aspects of emergency response

successCriteria: Assigns clear roles and responsibilities

unistructural.stem: What does RICER stand for in treating sprains?
unistructural.modelResponse: RICER stands for Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation, Referral (to medical help).
unistructural.rubric: Correctly identifies all components of RICER.

multistructural.stem: List the four steps in the asthma first aid procedure.
multistructural.modelResponse: The four steps for asthma first aid are: 1) Help the person sit upright and stay calm, 2) Help them take 4 puffs of their blue reliever inhaler (one puff at a time, 4 breaths per puff), 3) Wait 4 minutes, 4) If no improvement, give 4 more puffs and call Triple Zero if still not improving.
multistructural.rubric: Lists key steps including sitting upright, 4 puffs of reliever, waiting, and repeating/calling for help if needed.

relational.stem: Explain how chest compressions and rescue breaths work together during CPR to keep a person alive.
relational.modelResponse: Chest compressions and rescue breaths work together to replace the functions of the stopped heart and interrupted breathing. Compressions push down on the heart, squeezing blood out to the body and brain, keeping oxygen reaching vital organs. When you release, the chest rises and blood flows back into the heart. Rescue breaths put oxygen into the lungs, which then enters the blood. The 30:2 ratio means enough blood is moving (through continuous compressions) while periodically refreshing the oxygen supply (through breaths). Without compressions, oxygen in the blood can't reach the brain. Without breaths, the blood's oxygen supply runs out. Together they maintain circulation and oxygenation until the heart can restart.
relational.rubric: Explains how compressions create blood flow. Shows how breaths provide oxygen. Demonstrates understanding of why both are needed together.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider why first aid education is included in school curriculum but also requires practical training. What are the benefits and limitations of classroom learning compared to hands-on first aid courses?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Classroom education builds essential knowledge: understanding emergencies, knowing DRSABCD, recognising conditions, and knowing when to call for help. It reaches many students and provides theoretical foundations. However, limitations include: skills like CPR require muscle memory developed through practice on mannequins, students may freeze in real emergencies without rehearsal, and confidence comes from hands-on experience. Practical courses offer: muscle memory development, simulated emergency scenarios, feedback on technique, and confidence building. The ideal approach combines both - classroom for knowledge and awareness, practical for skill development. School education ensures everyone has basic knowledge, while practical courses (like those from St John or Red Cross) build capability. Together they create competent first aiders - people who know what to do and can actually do it under pressure.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies benefits and limitations of classroom learning. Explains what practical training adds. Shows understanding of how different learning approaches complement each other.

contentSections.title: The Chain of Survival
contentSections.content: The chain of survival describes the critical steps for cardiac arrest survival. Each 'link' must be strong for the best outcome. Early recognition and calling for help starts the chain. Early CPR doubles or triples survival rates by maintaining blood flow. Early defibrillation is the only effective treatment for certain cardiac rhythms - for every minute without defibrillation, survival drops by 7-10%. Advanced medical care continues the chain at hospital. Community factors like AED access, CPR training rates, and emergency response times affect how strong each link is. Understanding this helps target improvements in community emergency response.

contentSections.title: Scene Management and Triage
contentSections.content: When multiple people are involved in an emergency, scene management and triage become important. Scene management includes: securing the scene from further danger, delegating tasks to bystanders, managing onlookers, and coordinating with arriving emergency services. Triage involves prioritising casualties - those with life-threatening but survivable conditions get attention first. Simple triage categories include: immediate (life-threatening, survivable with treatment), delayed (serious but stable), and walking wounded (minor injuries). Taking control of a scene and directing others can improve outcomes significantly.

contentSections.title: Psychological First Aid
contentSections.content: Emergencies affect mental health as well as physical health. Psychological first aid supports people experiencing distress after traumatic events. Key principles include: promoting safety and calm, being present and supportive, helping connect with social supports, promoting self-efficacy and hope, and connecting to additional help if needed. Unlike physical first aid, psychological support continues after immediate danger has passed. Witnesses and first aiders may also experience distress and benefit from support. Schools and communities should include psychological support in emergency response planning.

contentSections.title: Community Emergency Preparedness
contentSections.content: Communities with good emergency preparedness have better outcomes. This includes: widespread first aid and CPR training, accessible AEDs in public locations, clear emergency plans for schools and workplaces, exercises and drills to practise responses, and good communication systems. Young people can contribute by: learning first aid skills, knowing their community's emergency plans, identifying gaps in preparedness, and advocating for improvements. The bystander effect (where people are less likely to help when others are present) can be overcome with training and clear instructions.

remember.question: What are the four links in the chain of survival?

options.text: Danger, Response, Send, Airway
options.feedback: These are steps in DRSABCD, not the chain of survival.

options.text: Early recognition and call for help, early CPR, early defibrillation, advanced medical care
options.feedback: Correct! These four links must all be strong for the best chance of survival from cardiac arrest.

options.text: Police, Fire, Ambulance, Hospital
options.feedback: These are emergency services, not the chain of survival links.

options.text: Check, Call, Care, Calm
options.feedback: This isn't the chain of survival terminology.

understand.question: Why does survival rate drop by 7-10% for every minute that defibrillation is delayed?

options.text: Because the defibrillator battery runs down
options.feedback: The decline is about what's happening to the patient, not the equipment.

options.text: Because without blood flow, brain cells are dying and the heart becomes less responsive to defibrillation
options.feedback: Correct! Oxygen deprivation causes progressive damage, and the heart's electrical system becomes less likely to respond to defibrillation over time.

options.text: Because people forget how to use the defibrillator
options.feedback: Modern AEDs provide voice prompts. The decline is due to physiological factors.

options.text: Because ambulances take that long to arrive
options.feedback: This is why early defibrillation by bystanders is important - we can't wait for ambulances.

apply.question: You're first on scene at a car accident with three injured people. One is conscious and walking, one is unconscious but breathing, one is not breathing. Apply triage principles - in what order do you help them?

options.text: Help the walking person first because they can talk to you
options.feedback: The walking person is 'walking wounded' - lower priority than those with more serious conditions.

options.text: Start with the unconscious breathing person because they're easiest to help
options.feedback: While they need the recovery position, the person not breathing is most critical.

options.text: The not-breathing person first (immediate), then unconscious-breathing (recovery position), the walking person last (delayed)
options.feedback: Correct! Triage prioritises immediately life-threatening conditions. Not breathing is most urgent, then airway management for unconscious, then care for stable/minor injuries.

options.text: Wait for the ambulance to arrive before doing anything
options.feedback: While calling Triple Zero, immediate care especially for the not-breathing person can be life-saving.

analyse.question: Analyse the bystander effect and explain why it occurs and how it can be overcome in emergency situations.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse: why it occurs (diffusion of responsibility - 'someone else will help', social influence - looking to others who aren't acting, evaluation apprehension - fear of looking foolish), and how to overcome it (training increases confidence and readiness to act, direct instructions - point and say 'you call 000', creating social norms that helping is expected). Strong responses connect psychological understanding to practical solutions.
successCriteria: Explains what the bystander effect is
Analyses psychological reasons it occurs
Proposes practical strategies to overcome it
Connects analysis to emergency response

evaluate.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of current community defibrillator placement and access in your local area. Consider availability, accessibility, awareness, and maintenance.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students evaluate local AED provision considering: number and locations of AEDs, accessibility (24/7 access, locked buildings), community awareness of locations, signage, maintenance and battery checks, and training availability. Evaluation should identify gaps and propose improvements. May include research on local AED registries.
successCriteria: Assesses current AED availability in local area
Evaluates accessibility and awareness
Considers maintenance and training factors
Proposes specific improvements

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive plan including: prevention/risk assessment, communication protocols (including to emergency services), assigned roles and responsibilities, equipment locations and maintenance, procedures for various scenarios, evacuation procedures if needed, provisions for people with medical conditions or disabilities, psychological first aid/post-event support, and plan review and practice schedule.

unistructural.stem: What is triage in emergency response?
unistructural.modelResponse: Triage is the process of prioritising casualties based on severity when multiple people are injured.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly defines triage as prioritising casualties based on severity/urgency.

multistructural.stem: List four elements of psychological first aid.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four elements of psychological first aid are: 1) Promoting safety and calm, 2) Being present and supportive, 3) Helping connect with social supports, 4) Promoting self-efficacy and hope.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant elements such as safety, calm, presence, support, connection, efficacy, hope, or referral to help.

relational.stem: Explain how improvements in one link of the chain of survival can affect overall survival rates.
relational.modelResponse: The chain of survival links are interconnected - improving one affects the whole chain. For example, increasing community CPR training strengthens the 'early CPR' link. This matters because CPR maintains some blood flow, keeping the brain and heart viable for longer. This means when the 'early defibrillation' link activates, the heart is more likely to respond successfully. Similarly, faster ambulance response times (advanced care link) means earlier professional intervention and transport to hospital. Weaknesses in one link can undo improvements in others - excellent CPR doesn't help if defibrillation is delayed 20 minutes. That's why community emergency preparedness needs to address multiple links simultaneously.
relational.rubric: Explains how one link affects others. Shows understanding of the chain as an interconnected system. Demonstrates why comprehensive improvement matters.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how emerging technologies might transform community emergency response in the future. What opportunities and challenges might arise?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Emerging technologies offer significant opportunities. Smartphone apps can locate nearby AEDs and alert trained bystanders to cardiac arrests before ambulances arrive. Drones could deliver AEDs to remote locations faster than ground vehicles. AI could help dispatch make better triage decisions. Wearable devices might detect cardiac problems before arrest occurs. However, challenges exist: privacy concerns with tracking and monitoring, equity issues if technology-dependent responses disadvantage some communities, over-reliance on technology when human skills remain essential, cybersecurity risks in connected systems, and need for systems to work when technology fails. The future likely involves technology augmenting human response rather than replacing it - expanding what bystanders can do with better tools and information while maintaining fundamental first aid skills.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies specific technological opportunities. Anticipates meaningful challenges. Shows understanding of technology as augmenting rather than replacing human response. Considers equity and reliability issues.

contentSections.title: Research on Emergency Outcomes
contentSections.content: Research shows significant variation in survival from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) between communities and countries. Factors affecting outcomes include: bystander CPR rates (vary from under 20% to over 70% internationally), time to defibrillation, emergency service response times, quality of post-resuscitation care, and population health factors. The Utstein style allows international comparison of outcomes. Social determinants also affect survival - areas with lower socioeconomic status often have lower survival rates due to differences in access, training, and response times. Understanding these factors allows targeted intervention.

contentSections.title: International Approaches to Emergency Response
contentSections.content: Countries take different approaches to emergency response. The Scandinavian model features high bystander CPR rates (70%+) through mandatory training in schools, widespread AED access, and smartphone apps alerting nearby volunteers. Japan has extensive public AED networks in urban areas. Some developing countries use community health workers for emergency response in areas with limited ambulance access. Dispatch-assisted CPR (where operators guide callers through CPR) has become standard in many systems. Evaluating approaches requires considering context - population density, resources, existing infrastructure, and cultural factors all affect what works.

contentSections.title: Innovation in Emergency Response
contentSections.content: Innovation is changing emergency response. Drone AED delivery can reach remote locations faster than ground vehicles - trials show significant time savings. Smartphone apps connect cardiac arrests to nearby trained bystanders. AI can help dispatchers identify cardiac arrest from call content. Mechanical CPR devices provide consistent compressions during transport. Targeted temperature management improves neurological outcomes after resuscitation. However, technological solutions must complement, not replace, fundamental community preparedness - training, AED access, and willingness to help remain essential.

contentSections.title: Building Community Resilience
contentSections.content: Community resilience encompasses preparation for, response to, and recovery from emergencies of all types. This includes: all-hazards emergency planning, community training and exercises, social connections that support mutual aid, infrastructure that remains functional, and systems for recovery support. Research shows that communities with strong social connections recover faster from disasters. Young people can contribute to resilience through skills, volunteering, advocacy, and maintaining social networks. Building resilience is ongoing work, not a one-time activity.

remember.question: What is the Utstein style in cardiac arrest research?

options.text: A particular technique for performing CPR
options.feedback: The Utstein style refers to reporting standards, not CPR technique.

options.text: An international standardised method for reporting cardiac arrest data to allow comparison
options.feedback: Correct! The Utstein style enables comparison of cardiac arrest outcomes between systems and countries.

options.text: A type of defibrillator design from Norway
options.feedback: While developed in Utstein, Norway, the Utstein style is a reporting template, not a device.

options.text: A style of emergency response uniform
options.feedback: The Utstein style is about data reporting, not uniforms.

understand.question: Why do social determinants affect emergency survival rates?

options.text: Because people in disadvantaged areas are less healthy
options.feedback: While health differences exist, the question is about emergency response factors.

options.text: Because factors like income and location affect access to training, AEDs, and response times
options.feedback: Correct! Social determinants create differences in preparedness resources and emergency service access.

options.text: Because ambulance staff treat people differently based on where they live
options.feedback: The issue is systemic access and resources, not discrimination by individual responders.

options.text: Because social determinants don't actually affect outcomes
options.feedback: Research clearly shows social determinants do affect emergency outcomes.

apply.question: A rural community has very low bystander CPR rates and long ambulance response times. Apply the Scandinavian model principles to suggest improvements.

options.text: Just wait for more ambulances to be built
options.feedback: This doesn't address bystander response, which is crucial in rural areas with long response times.

options.text: Introduce CPR training in schools, establish community first responder networks, deploy AEDs in key locations, and consider dispatch-assisted CPR
options.feedback: Correct! These adapt Scandinavian principles (widespread training, community responders, AED access, dispatch guidance) to rural context.

options.text: Tell people to drive themselves to hospital
options.feedback: Self-transport is not appropriate for cardiac arrest and delays professional care.

options.text: Focus only on improving hospital care
options.feedback: Improving early links in the chain of survival is essential - hospital care alone can't compensate for delayed initial response.

analyse.question: Analyse the potential benefits and challenges of using drone-delivered AEDs in emergency response systems.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple dimensions. Benefits: faster delivery to remote locations, overcome traffic delays, reach difficult terrain, extend coverage area. Challenges: weather limitations, regulatory barriers, maintenance costs, airspace management, need for bystanders willing and able to use the AED, noise in residential areas, reliability. Strong responses consider how drones fit within broader systems rather than as standalone solutions.
successCriteria: Identifies multiple potential benefits
Analyses implementation challenges
Considers how drones fit within broader emergency systems
Shows sophisticated understanding of the tradeoffs

evaluate.question: Evaluate the statement: 'The best investment to improve cardiac arrest survival is more ambulances and paramedics.' Do you agree or disagree? Justify your evaluation with evidence.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should critically evaluate this statement. While ambulances and paramedics are important, research shows that bystander CPR and early defibrillation have the largest impact on survival - these happen before ambulances arrive. Communities with high bystander CPR rates outperform those with fast ambulances but low bystander rates. Investment should address all links in the chain. Strong responses use evidence (international comparisons, survival statistics) to justify their position.
successCriteria: Evaluates the statement critically, not just agrees or disagrees
Uses evidence about chain of survival to justify position
Recognises the role of both bystander and professional response
Makes a reasoned judgment about investment priorities

shortAnswer.rubric: Students design a comprehensive system for their chosen context. Design should demonstrate synthesis of research evidence with innovative thinking.

unistructural.stem: What is return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC)?
unistructural.modelResponse: ROSC is when a heart starts beating again on its own after cardiac arrest.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly defines ROSC as the heart resuming beating on its own after arrest.

multistructural.stem: List four factors that research shows affect survival from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four factors affecting survival from OHCA are: 1) Bystander CPR rates, 2) Time to defibrillation, 3) Emergency service response times, 4) Quality of post-resuscitation care.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant factors. May include bystander CPR, defibrillation time, response times, post-resuscitation care, public AED access, or dispatcher-assisted CPR.

relational.stem: Explain how the Scandinavian approach to cardiac arrest response creates a self-reinforcing system of improvement.
relational.modelResponse: The Scandinavian approach creates a self-reinforcing system through interconnected elements. Mandatory CPR training in schools means most adults have skills. High training rates increase willingness to help - people feel confident to act. More bystander CPR leads to better outcomes, which motivates continued training investment. Public AED networks complement training - people know where to find them and how to use them. Data collection and research (using Utstein style) identifies what works, informing further improvements. Success stories from survivors encourage community engagement. Apps connecting volunteers to emergencies build community of responders. Each improvement supports others, creating momentum for continued advancement. This differs from one-off interventions - it's a comprehensive, evolving system.
relational.rubric: Explains how multiple elements of the system reinforce each other. Shows understanding of system dynamics rather than just listing components. Identifies feedback loops that create improvement momentum.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how climate change might affect emergency response needs and capabilities in Australian communities over the next 30 years. What adaptations might be needed?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Climate change will affect both emergency needs and response capacity. Increased extreme weather events (bushfires, floods, heatwaves) will create more mass casualty incidents, overwhelming traditional response systems. Prolonged events may exhaust responder capacity. Heatwaves particularly affect cardiac patients, potentially increasing cardiac arrests while making outdoor response more dangerous. Infrastructure damage may impair ambulance access and hospital capacity. Some communities may need to relocate or be seasonally inaccessible. Adaptations needed include: building community self-reliance for periods of isolation, pre-positioning resources based on seasonal risk, heat-adapted protocols for responders, regional surge capacity for mass events, integration of emergency management with climate adaptation planning, and addressing social determinants that make some communities more vulnerable. Emergency response must evolve from episodic crisis response to part of ongoing climate adaptation. Young people will experience these changes throughout their lives, making this both a policy and personal issue.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies specific climate change impacts on emergencies. Proposes meaningful adaptations across multiple areas. Shows understanding of systems-level changes needed. Connects to both current planning and long-term futures.
